@ScottACroucher Even just from Cherry:
Blue: tactile "bump" part of the way down (where it triggers), plus a click.
Brown: bump, no click. Softer than blue too.
Red: Linear switch, like pressing a spring. No bump or click. Blacks are a stiffer version of reds.
Etc. Get a tester to try them!

@ScottACroucher It's a more nuanced typing experience. I find that, subjectively, it feels softer on the wrists, but naturally requires more finger-extension. This is the kind of keyboard I mostly used until I was in my twenties. There are plenty of other switch types too.

@ScottACroucher Well, there's a great deal more travel; probably 3-4x times the Magic Keyboard. But these are Cherry MX Blue switches, so the actuation/click point is part of the way down. You don't need to "bottom out" (fully depress) the key for it to register, so it feels softer than the MK.

If I was going to use a desktop computer again, it'd be a Mac; no question. But I really don't want to. Thank deity for iWork, Ulysses, Scrivener, Things, Omni & Panic apps, Office, Affinity's apps, and — OK — even Photoshop next year, on iOS. Don't make me go back to the Mac!

Trackpads feel so _weird_ to me now. It's 90° off-axis from the pointer, and like 15 centimetres away. It's like I'm controlling a robot arm in the next room. And all the targets are tiny. And it has a bizarre obsession with the filesystem, which I don't care about. And so on.

Nonetheless, using a modern, touch-based device — which means the interaction design much more than the hardware — for two years really changes your perspective. You get used to how streamlined and human-optimised things can be. Going back to the Mac, it's busy and confusing.

I love the Mac community. I loved System 6, and 7, and Mac OS 8 and 9, and NeXTSTEP. I stood in line for Mac OS X 10.0, and .1, and .2 etc. I _loved_ being a Cocoa developer, and an iOS developer. I wrote a lot of code for Apple, mostly for macOS. I am A HUGE MAC FAN.

I should make this clear: I love the Mac. Love it; so much. It's why I got interested in software development as a real job, rather than programming as a hobby. It's thus why I got my degree in Comp Sci, and met my wife. I've had a fantastic prior career that stemmed from it.
